channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems.

item.title: Music-loving DevOps (with Perl), get in here! London based role
item.description: We’ve got an intriguing role for a Lead DevOps Engineer who cares about great music. Our client knows all about how you listen to music: as an independent global music business, they work with artists, labels, and distributors to release and sell music on their digital platform.

item.title: Thought-Leader Wanted. Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia (or elsewhere)
item.description: As Chief Software Architect for an international company providing online trading services, you’ll work closely with the Chief Technology Officer. With a strong understanding of the full stack of software development and cloud technologies, you’ll mentor engineering teams and provide guidance in solving technical issues.

item.title: Is your Python as good as your Perl? Perl/Python role in London
item.description: This role is for a Senior Developer who is equally comfortable with Perl AND Python. If you’re stronger with Perl than Python or vice-versa, you should be willing to brush up on your knowledge until you’re fluent in both. You’ll use server-side code, client-side code, databases, and websites to develop their software platform.

item.title: Software Developer or Matchmaker? Semi-Remote Perl Role in Manchester
item.description: Our client's mission is to connect folks in the UK and US seeking flatmates or homes to share. If you’re a Software Developer (Backend), these flatmate matchmakers want you to increase the delivery capacity of their team. With a core platform that is mostly written in Perl, you’ll work with developers to create admin tools and implement and test new site features.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 168 › Home Prime
item.description: I loved the comparison of recursive and iterative solutions. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC 168 › Perrin Primes
item.description: I am very impressed with the presentation of blog. There is plenty to learn from him. Highly recommended as always.

item.title: At Home with the Perrins
item.description: Ruby is the favourite language this week. Although it is new to me but blog makes it so easy to follow. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: More funny numbers ... and a very big one
item.description: Peter's use of f(23) is quite interesting. The short and precise discussion makes it all fun to read. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 168
item.description: Luis one-liner in Perl is very special as always. The use of CPAN module makes it even fun. Well done and keep it up.

item.title: prime numbers is many ways!
item.description: Luca never misses the opportunity to impress with his Raaku skill. We also got bonus PostgreSQL solutions too. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 168: Perrin Primes
item.description: Laurent has been contributing in Perl and Raku but for me, his Raku contribution stands out. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 168
item.description: James, being the most daring contributors, he lived upto his reputation, once again. You don't want to miss out. Highly recommended.

item.title: PWC168 - Home Prime
item.description: I love 'The questions' section more than the solution itself to be honest. I know, too many prime number related tasks, being served in recent weeks. Thank you for support and contribution.

item.title: PWC168 - Perrin Prime
item.description: Flavio mostly blog about Perl but for weekly challenge he makes sure to contribute in Raku as well. Keep it up great work.

item.title: This Is Gonna Take FOREVER!
item.description: Dave not only shared his Perl contributions but also gave me idea for new challenge. Thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.

item.title: Primarily Prime
item.description: Arne also shares Perl and Raku solutions. I noticed Raku being his first love, his Perl solutions is also top notch every week. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Take the Long Way Home
item.description: Great show of code reuse and CPAN, promoting the idea 'don't reinvent the wheel'. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 162
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 168
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Perrin Prime" and "Home Prime" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 169
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Brilliant Numbers" and "Achilles Numbers". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Looking for a new owner for my modules
item.description: Damien is looking for helping hand to maintain some of his CPAN work. If you are interested and have time to dedicate then please do help him.

item.title: Reconsidering the licensing of Perl code
item.description: Licensing is a tricky business. In the post, Dean helping us explain the nitty-gritty.

item.title: Cleaner code with perl 5.36 and defer
Entering the Charts
item.description: Kephra presenting Charts for Perl fans. Please checkout the blog for the ground work behind it. Well done.

item.title: Core Modules: filetest
item.description: Tom shared the details of filetest pragma in the light of latest Perl v5.36. A very nice introduction, not to be missed.

item.title: Memory Leak in Perl
item.description: Memory management in Perl never an issue for many. In the blog, I tried to scratch the surface.

item.title: Taint in Perl
item.description: Dealing with taint was always a mystery to me. In this blog, I share my experience dealing with taint in Perl.

item.title: Do you want to get started with Perl v5.36?
item.description: Here is my personal journey with the latest Perl release.

item.title: Curses::UI data viewer becomes dew
item.description: Structure data viewer got new home. Nice demo of Perl power.

item.title: #568 - Perl v5.36 - the beginning of new era
item.description:
Hi there,

A big round of applause to the entire team behind the ground breaking release of Perl v5.36. I have been following the features of the latest release very closely. I am confident it would be a solid foundation for Corinna and v7.

Have you had chance to play with Perl v5.36?

If not then please do checkout my blog post, where I shared my first hand experience playing with Perl v5.36.

Have you ever thought of contributing to your favourite language, Perl?

A little over a decade, I submitted a small patch via email. Those days, the process was not as smooth as it is today. Unfortunately I never received any acknowledgment. Ever since Perl, found the new home in GitHub, it is so easy to submit the patches. I submitted a small change to the core Perl. To my surprise, in 2 days, it got accepted and merged. It has given me confidence to submit more.

Why don't you also give it a try?

Last but not least, I would like to thank each and everyone for all the support via Patreon, I received in the last few weeks. I am overwhelmed, to be honest.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
